publications.title: GST and the Price Puzzle: Consumer Behavior, Industry Strategies, and Policy Lessons from India and Abroad
publications.deck: This research investigates how changes in India’s Goods and Services Tax (GST) reshape consumer behavior, industry pricing strategies, and supply chain dynamics across major sectors. By comparing theory with real-world outcomes—and drawing lessons from international GST/VAT regimes—it highlights unintended distortions, behavioral shifts, and policy pathways to align tax design with affordability, competitiveness, and growth.
keyTakeaways: Psychological Lens on Taxation: GST changes affect not only prices but also consumer trust, timing of purchases, and perception of affordability across essential vs discretionary goods.
Industry Adaptation Matters: Firms adjust via packaging, sourcing, pricing, and marketing strategies, often diluting or amplifying the intended consumer benefits of GST reforms.
Supply Chain Paradoxes: Exemptions and inverted duty structures can create cost burdens that paradoxically raise prices for “tax-free” goods, undermining GST’s efficiency.

Sector-Specific Divergence: While sectors like FMCG or textiles may pass GST cuts to consumers, industries like real estate and automobiles exhibit partial or distorted transmission, creating gaps between theory and practice.

Policy & Global Lessons: International GST/VAT experiences show that simplification (fewer slabs, zero-rating essentials) reduces distortions. India can adapt these lessons to refine its GST, ensuring better alignment of policy intent with ground reality.
